item.title: Poll: So, Should Pok√©mon Red And Blue Return For The 30th Anniversary?
item.content:encoded:
Or maybe FireRed and LeafGreen?

With Pok√©mon's 30th anniversary celebrations underway, fans are quite rightly curious about how Nintendo and The Pok√©mon Company might acknowledge the games that started it all.

Yes, without Pok√©mon Red and Blue (and Green), there would be no Pok√©mon and no 30th anniversary celebrations. Almost 10 years ago for the 20th anniversary, classic Pok√©mon games were added to the 3DS eShop on 27th February 2016. Users could buy these √† la carte, long before Nintendo started to lean on subscription models for its retro games, and it made for an appropriate way to acknowledge the important milestone.

A new, unsubstantiated rumour from known Pok√©mon leaker Riddler_Khu (thanks, Vice Gaming) suggests that Nintendo might be gearing up to launch Pok√©mon FireRed and LeafGreen on the Switch for the 30th anniversary.

It's not clear whether these might be available via Nintendo Switch online or as standalone purchases (or, indeed, whether it's even a remotely credible claim at all), but it would make for a substantial addition to the GBA catalogue. Certainly, it would convince many Switch Online subscribers to upgrade to the more expensive Expansion Pack tier.

Whether this claim from Riddler_Khu is credible or not (and history suggests that their trustworthiness is sketchy at best these days), it's nevertheless inspired us to speculate on whether classic Pok√©mon games will make a return for the 30th anniversary. And if they will, in what form should they take?

So, let us know what you think, dear readers, by voting in the below polls and leaving a comment in the usual place.

item.title: 1,200 Ubisoft Employees Kicked Off Three-Day International Strike in Response to Company‚Äôs ‚ÄúMajor Reset‚Äù
item.content:encoded:
At the start of 2026, Ubisoft didn't just announce layoffs at one of its studios (which is how it started 2025). It announced a "major reset," which included layoffs at multiple studios, the shuttering of Ubisoft Halifax, the cancellation of the Prince of Persia: Sands of Time Remake, and significant changes to its operating structure, alongside some unpopular new policies like a return-to-office mandate.

The response to these changes has not exactly been positive, both internally within Ubisoft and externally across the industry. On the stock market, the announcement of the restructure saw the company's stock price drop 34%, which officially saw Ubisoft lose 95% of its value in just eight years. When this restructuring was followed by the introduction of a voluntary redundancy program at Ubisoft's headquarters in Paris, which aimed to cut as many as 200 employees, employees decided they had had enough.

French union Solidaires Informatique, which represents several employees at Ubisoft Paris, announced plans for an international strike, calling on Ubisoft employees at branches across the globe to walk out and strike on February 10, 11, and 12. Yesterday, February 10, 2026, was the first day of the strike, and according to Solidaires Informatique (via GamesIndustry.Biz), at least 1,200 Ubisoft employees walked out yesterday to participate in the strike.

Most of the striking employees came from within France, with some of the striking workers also coming from the Milan branch. It's a strong show of force from Ubisoft employees, who have been calling out the company's leadership, specifically chief executive officer Yves Guillemot, as the responsible party for the studio's woes.

Employees are still on strike today, and will be for the remainder of the week. This is also not the only demonstration that has already happened, as former staff from the now-shuttered Halifax branch held a rally last month in response to their studio getting suddenly shut down.

Solidaires Informatique already hosted a smaller strike last month that it called an "initial answer to the absurdity of management's decisions." Solidaires Informatique representative, Marc Rutschl√©, also added, "At this state, it seems clear to us that Yves Guillemot has no knowledge or understanding of his company or its employees."

"The company is continuing its cost reduction and layoff plan. Our teams are already working under pressure, often understaffed. After several years without pay rises (or very small increases), we understand that once again, employees will not receive a raise this year. At the same time, the reorganization is creating a number of high-level positions with excessive salaries."

"From our union's point of view, this forced reversal is a disguised redundancy plan, aimed at pushing employees outside the company. The atmosphere within the studio is particularly deplorable, with anger and despair reigning supreme. Staff representatives have witnessed several breakdowns in tears; some colleagues have made suicidal comments. If Guillemot wanted to make people miserable, he couldn't have done better."

item.title: Bonfire Studio‚Äôs Mix of Diablo, PUBG, and Dark Souls, Arkheron, Will Get a Steam Next Fest Demo Ahead of Launch Later This Year
item.content:encoded:
Arkheron, the interesting and ambitious blend between Diablo, PUBG, and Dark Souls from Bonfire Studios, which we first got a look at last September. It will have its first public playtest via the launch of a brand new demo arriving on February 20, 2026, just ahead of the first Steam Next Fest of 2026, which will officially kick off three days later on February 23.

The news of the new demo also came along with a new trailer, where Bonfire Studios takes players through some of its plans for Arkheron as the team gets closer to launch, and some of the changes and updates players who've previously participated in the game's alpha playtest weekends will notice.

Introduced in the demo will be two new Eternal item sets that Bonfire will reveal just ahead of the demo's actual release, though with that also means two current sets players are already familiar with will be removed for the demo. They're not going away permanently; it's just a switch Bonfire is making for now, and since part of the fun in Arkheron is mixing and matching items and abilities to create more powerful characters, it's all part of Bonfire giving players as many options on how to play as possible.

The demo also arrives with a new patch for the game, version 0.16, which adds a new tutorial, regional server selections, environmental updates and the ability to go back through your recent teammates if you want to keep playing with someone you randomly met through the game.

Once the demo goes live on February 20, players will be able to jump in 24/7 until March 2, 2026, when the demo goes offline. If Arkheron strikes you as something you want to keep playing, however, Bonfire is hosting another closed beta to help the studio further refine the game ahead of launch. The closed beta will introduce a ranked mode and will be focused on ensuring the game's competitive progression is finely tuned.

You will need to be sent a key to access the closed beta, so if you're enjoying Arkheron during Steam Next Fest, make sure to sign up for the closed beta to potentially participate in it.

item.title: Starsand Island Preview - Ambitious Island Adventure
item.content:encoded:
Every Farming RPG is a little bit different. Starsand Island promises to deliver all of the hallmarks of the genre with an unprecedented amount of freedom. In this Starsand Island preview, I set out to explore the world that Seed Sparkle Lab has built and see what makes this game so special.

Starsand Island tells the classic Farming RPG tale of a young adult returning to a place they once visited as a child. You get a plot of land and a decent enough tutorial, and then you're off to explore a game filled with tons of fun activities. It seemed like an ambitious project, and I was not disappointed by how the devs delivered.

Returning Home

As is typical for the genre, Starsand Island starts by giving you the basics ‚Äî character creation, a short story introduction, a small plot of land, and a serviceable tutorial. This game also maintains the tradition of a high amount of player freedom; once you've started, you have a lot of different ways to play.

A central aspect of Starsand Island is its profession system. There are five Professions in total ‚Äî crafting, farming, fishing, ranching, and exploration ‚Äî and each of them has unique quest chains that allow you to advance deeper into their respective crafting trees.

Starsand Island lets you decide exactly how you want to play and how fast you want to go through its content.

Crafting, in particular, is essential to life on the island, and this is why the tutorial recommends that you work on it first. You'll need to use the workbenches and crafting materials you make with the crafting profession to create equipment for the other four professions at one point or another, unless you want to do things the slow way.

That's not to say the profession system is overly restrictive, mind. I started the quest chains for all five professions and played through them concurrently, bouncing back and forth based on my interests at the time. Starsand Island lets you decide exactly how you want to play and how fast you want to go through its content.

Growing Your Farm

Naturally, farming is a big part of a game like this. Starsand Island offers a fairly robust farming system with seasonal crops, fruit trees, and multiple ways to plant your favorite foods. The pacing with this particular profession, however, is a little bit unusual.

Any Stardew Valley veteran worth his salt will tell you that sprinklers are essential to farming at scale, and you can usually start to make them fairly early. Conversely, Starsand Island buries the required equipment about halfway through the farming and crafting professions, respectively; it takes quite some time to get there.

You'll need a fair amount of materials to make sprinklers, too, and that means a lot of runs into the Moonlit Forest to go mining for resources. Essentially, having the most basic of automation on your farm requires a fair amount of progress in three of the five professions.

Farming gets easier as you go, but it's not quite the cozy moneymaker that you'd expect from some other Farming RPGs. Sowing, watering, weeding, and harvesting crops are all done one at a time until you can progress deeper into multiple professions and craft yourself some better equipment.

Building Your Homestead

One of Starsand Island's most notable features is its building system. Many games in the Farming RPG and survival genres allow you to build structures piece by piece, but Starsand Island gives you what I believe to be one of the most robust building systems ever seen in a game of this style.

You're automatically given a cozy one-room, Asian-style shack as your home. It has enough space for the basics, but you might want to expand if you want to avoid having dozens of crafting stations strewn about on your front lawn. This is where you have two choices: layouts and free building.

In addition to the nearly one thousand furniture items you can unlock in the game, you can also place nearly every other item in the game as decoration, such as crops, cooked food, tools, and some (but not all) of the crafting materials you come across.

If desired, you can purchase a pre-made layout and simply plop it down on some empty land. There are a few choices of varying architectural styles, and you can additionally modify the design yourself once it's placed.

The much more attractive option (to me, at least) is the free building system. You can place blocks, roof pieces, doors, and windows piece by piece. You can scale them to larger sizes. You can change their texture. You can build yourself a simple grey box for your stuff, or you can spend hours building the perfect home.

Starsand Island takes things even further with its decorations. In addition to the nearly one thousand furniture items you can unlock in the game, you can also place nearly every other item in the game as decoration, such as crops, cooked food, tools, and some (but not all) of the crafting materials you come across.

Fighting Through the Forest

Peaceful as it may seem, this beautiful island paradise is not free from conflict. The Moonlit Forest pulls double duty as both the main dungeon and the mines, and you're going to have to visit it a lot to get all of the raw materials you need to advance your professions and make useful equipment.

The Moonlit Forest is one of the weaker areas of Starsand Island in its current state. You can run end-to-end and encounter fewer than 10 enemies and a grand total of three minibosses. Combat doesn't feel particularly challenging, either.

Though lacking in enemies, the Moonlit Forest more than makes up for it with an abundant amount of unique plants, trees, and raw ore. These items spawn in the same place every day, and you'll likely find yourself visiting the same spots daily to collect another backpack full of iron or gold.

Mining in the Moonlit Forest was always one area where I never felt like I had enough time or energy. If I needed certain materials, I'd easily burn up half of my day slogging through the dungeon to get everything I need. This aspect of Starsand Island could do with some improvement in the future.

Forging Friendships

The one element I haven't yet addressed in Starsand Island is the friendship system. There are friendship meters, a gifting system, and a way to hire certain townspeople to work for you once you've advanced your relationship enough.

That said, there's a near-total lack of meaningful story development with any of the characters, outside of the mentors you interact with during the five profession quest chains. There isn't much in the way of heart events or unique stories to uncover from what I've seen.

Maxing out a friendship meter allows you to invite your "friend" to move in with you ‚Äî a feat I've yet to achieve ‚Äî but there is no clear language on romance or marriage just yet. It's a strange omission.

In Seed Sparkle Lab's defense, this is one of the elements that many Farming RPGs tend to roll out in stages. Fields of Mistria, for example, only had the most basic of story events in its Early Access launch version; many other games in this space tend to use the same playbook.

I am further confused by the vague language surrounding romance. Maxing out a friendship meter allows you to invite your "friend" to move in with you ‚Äî a feat I've yet to achieve ‚Äî but there is no clear language on romance or marriage just yet. It's a strange omission.

Starsand Island Preview | Final Thoughts

All in all, Starsand Island is definitely one of the better Early Access Farming RPGs that I've played in recent years. The few bugs I've encountered have been relatively small, and many of them were fixed in the course of my time with a pre-launch version of the game.

While it's currently a little weak on the story and combat aspects, Starsand Island is mechanically robust, engaging, and ‚Äî most importantly ‚Äî fun. The building system is especially entertaining to me, and I struggled to resist the urge to spend countless hours building out the island home of my dreams.

As always, the main concerns with an Early Access game are how fast it can squash bugs and deliver new content. As important as this is, what you'll get with the Early Access launch version is an estimated 100 hours of gameplay. I'd wager you'd get even more than that if you take your time to enjoy it.

I'm excited to see how Starsand Island grows and develops in the coming months. If you're a fan of Farming RPGs and life sims (or if you're even remotely interested in these genres), then I can confidently say that Starsand Island is the first must-play game of the year in this space. Give it a chance ‚Äî you won't be disappointed.

Starsand Island was previewed over approximately 85 hours of gameplay on PC via Steam with a key provided by the publisher. All screenshots were taken during the preview process.

item.title: Come shout down dystopia in the demo for Amanita's fancy cardboard mind control puzzler Phonopolis
item.content:encoded:
Czech indie developers Amanita Design ‚Äì creators of Samorost, Creaks and Machinarium, among other marvels ‚Äì have released a demo for Phonopolis, their 3D cardboard adventure about a young man called Felix who is trying to save a city brainwashed by massive loudspeakers. Protected by his headphones, Felix is on a mission to stop the authoritarian Leader from issuing the Absolute Tone, which will ‚Äústrip every citizen of their humanity forever‚Äù. Seems like a thing to avoid!

I relate intensely to Felix at the moment, because I‚Äôm having trouble with my lugholes and can barely hear anything. Thank to the magic of medicinal drops, I, too, am proof against sonic mind control, but also, I am feeling more than usually susceptible to assassination. A marching band could backstab me right now. It‚Äôs not clear from the Steam page whether Felix‚Äôs indispensable headphones leave him similarly vulnerable. I guess we‚Äôll have to play the demo to find out.

‚ÄúWith Felix becoming immune to the commands, you‚Äôll be able to take advantage of the loudspeakers and use them to solve puzzles involving other characters,‚Äù the developers explain. ‚ÄúOther times, you will interact with the cardboard environment in surprising, often unexpected ways‚Äîturn walls, shuffle floors, control various machinery or tear paper curtains. Each puzzle is carefully integrated into the world and presents a different challenge.‚Äù

Those cardboard sets ‚Äì all based on physical, hand-painted sets, with animations capping out at 12 FPS in mimicry of stop-motion film ‚Äì certainly do look very inviting. But hang on, what‚Äôs this? Felix can ‚Äútake advantage‚Äù of the very same loudspeakers that have subjugated his fellow citizens? The master's tools will never dismantle the master's house, Amanita!

Being an Amanita joint, Phonopolis is openly steeped in art history. ‚ÄúThe art style is strongly influenced by avant-garde artistic trends of the interwar period such as constructivism, futurism, and suprematism, and their societal impact as a tool of propaganda,‚Äù the Steam page goes on.

That‚Äôs a lot of isms, more than is generally advisable, but I trust them to stick the landing. There‚Äôs also a sentence about the soundtrack, but I can offer no further comment there because, as of writing, you could set fire to a sackful of lions in my vicinity and I‚Äôd be none the wiser. Do your worst, *checks TV Tropes*... Jesse Custers of the world! The full version of Phonopolis releases sometime this year.

item.title: Overwatch Is Roaring Back On Steam After Massive Season 1 Patch
item.content:encoded:
For the first time in years, I had a full five-stack in Overwatch. Friends who had dropped Blizzard‚Äôs hero shooter years before and hadn‚Äôt given the game so much as a glance were finally back after the company added five new heroes, restructured its seasonal rollout to incorporate story, and dropped that pesky 2 from the title. They weren‚Äôt the only ones, either. Overwatch reached a new all-time peak on Steam last night with over 165,000 concurrent players logging in on the launcher. Not bad considering it was, at one point, one of the lowest-reviewed games on the platform.

That said, Overwatch is a multiplatform game, and a lot of PC players use Battle.net anyway, so that‚Äôs only a small slice of the people who flooded the servers yesterday. I actually had to wait in a queue for probably the first time since Overwatch 2‚Äôs launch in 2022. But once I got in, I immediately queued up as my longtime mains while everyone else was trying out the new heroes like a hydrogen bomb descending upon a coughing baby. I kid, mostly. I did put in a fair bit of time as Mizuki, the new support who throws his not-magic hat around the field to heal his teammates. Thankfully, the first night wasn‚Äôt just mirror matches of the five new heroes the whole time, as a lot of people just logged on to play as their main for a few matches.

But in the midst of all those matches, my friends who had long been skeptics of Overwatch‚Äôs return in a post-PvE cancelation world were hootin‚Äô, hollerin‚Äô, and admitting that the game ‚Äúmight be good‚Äù again. To which I say, I told you so. I‚Äôm glad to see so many people coming back and seeing how Blizzard managed to salvage a game after years of mismanagement and corporate sabotage. 

Sure, we‚Äôre probably in a honeymoon phase. The new heroes have injected a bunch of chaos into the mix, and viral clips of ridiculous plays with the tether-sporting Jetpack Cat are spreading like wildfire. When the dust settles, we‚Äôll probably talk about hero balance again, and Blizzard may rein in some of these antics, but it feels good to see Overwatch so reinvigorated all at once. This isn‚Äôt solely a result of the influx of new playable heroes, but also of the fact that Blizzard is pretty committed to its story integration. We‚Äôve gotten what feel like weekly lore updates, and even gotten another audio drama starring Freja and newcomer Emre that is actually feeding into the internal push and pull between Vendetta and those who have been part of the terrorist organization Talon.

Fans have been discovering new layers to characters‚Äô relationships through both the lore drops and the new dialogue before matches. There‚Äôs a lot of interpersonal drama with actual momentum now, with characters talking to each other about the state of the world after Vendetta defeated Doomfist, and maps like Watchpoint Gibraltar and Colesseo changing things in the environment and layout as part of the current narrative. 

Some of the best character stuff is, unsurprisingly given the theme of the season, coming from the characters who have defected from Talon. Sombra, Reaper, and Widowmaker are on the run after Vendetta‚Äôs hostile takeover, and dialogue implies that they‚Äôre all part of a tenuous partnership without the Talon banner uniting them. 

New Widowmaker and Sombra interaction!

"Not like I didn't warn the boss, but hard to believe Vendetta is starting a war." pic.twitter.com/i4O5BjkXqz

‚Äî Shroomiiee (@mushroomiiee) February 11, 2026

One of the most devastating subplots revealed in the game‚Äôs dialogue is Sigma‚Äôs. The mad scientist character has been conspicuously absent from the season‚Äôs cinematic, comic, and audio dramas, but he is also a member of Talon. However, it sounds like Vendetta views him more as a danger to be held captive, and he misses his friend Sombra, who had to cut and run. If Sigma kills Sombra in a match, he utters a devastated ‚ÄúBut I still need you,‚Äù or solemnly wonders where his friend has gone. That shit hurts real good. The Overwatch website has updated several of its heroes‚Äô story blurbs and confirms that Sombra is ‚Äúkeeping a careful eye‚Äù on Talon while Sigma is imprisoned, so maybe a jailbreak is in order later down the season?

So remember how Sigma kinda got no mentions during the setup for this new season besides a new lore blurb today? Turns out‚Ä¶he is not happy @OW2voicelines

RELEASE MY GOAT! RELEASE HIM pic.twitter.com/iJB0hhFz5C

‚Äî Jetpack Uniwatch (@UniwatchOW) February 11, 2026

It‚Äôs not all angst, though. The slew of new hero interactions is giving fans a lot to work with in terms of understanding new, budding relationships. Where once Overwatch said shipping wasn‚Äôt a priority in its worldbuilding, there are a bunch of characters with romantic tension in 2026, and that rocks, actually. Lifeweaver and Baptiste feel like they blazed a trail for heroes to start flirting in pre-matches, and now that the story actually has momentum, maybe ships like Wuyang and Juno or Kiriko and Mizuki can go somewhere. We‚Äôre already getting a lot of Freja and Emre, who seem to be canonically ex-lovers, so let‚Äôs spread the love, Blizzard. Except for Soldier: 76, who will likely remain a yearner.

BYE MILKYWAVE IS REAL, I TOLLDDD U BRUH I TOLLDD UUUU #milkywave pic.twitter.com/DTF7gppUNV

‚Äî korti üç™ (@PPYCH0W) February 11, 2026

Overall, it‚Äôs kind of wild to feel like there‚Äôs reason to hope for Overwatch again. The PvE campaign didn‚Äôt pan out, but the game we have feels more focused and dedicated to delivering a story with momentum, an ever-evolving competitive game with new heroes shaking things up every season, and in-game events to keep people showing up all year. It feels like we‚Äôre back in 2016 when the possibilities seemed endless. Here‚Äôs hoping Blizzard makes the most of this fresh start.

item.title: Arc Raiders‚Äô Latest Cheating Exploits Are The Worst The Extraction Shooter‚Äôs Ever Seen
item.content:encoded:
Poor Arc Raiders, after having a pretty smooth run from launch until the end of 2025, has since started springing leaks faster than developers Embark Studios can plug them up. After cheating scandals and item-duplication glitches that have been pissing off its player base, it now seems the latest update has introduced both a weapon-repairing glitch and a way to make infinite ammo. And worse, they‚Äôre both incredibly easy to pull off.

Usually when we see reports of a new way of glitching something in an online game, it turns out to be an action so complicated that only the most elite and dedicated players would ever even try. Unfortunately, that‚Äôs very much not the case in the latest issues to plague the excellent extraction shooter. It‚Äôs as simple and clicking back and forth in your inventory, then dropping and picking up weapons. And that means everyone‚Äôll be doing it.

Brought to wide attention by X user @genos, both the weapon-fixing and ammo-generating glitches use much the same technique. If you have a couple of worn weapons and want them repaired, all you need to do is rapidly switch them between your two weapon slots and for some reason their numbers start to climb. To make this stick, you then need to drop the weapon on the floor and pick it up again.

NEW REPAIR GLITCH IN ARC RAIDERS. #ArcRaiders pic.twitter.com/GCKXkAXL3K

‚Äî perc (@genos) February 11, 2026

Weapons wear down in Arc Raiders in order to prevent players from being able to overly rely on a particularly expensive, particularly powerful choice, which would reduce the sense of danger when on a raid. It‚Äôs a crucial part of the game‚Äôs already shaky balance, as much as it might annoy a player in the moment. As such, being able to fix up the most costly, most dangerous guns means people are able to become significantly overpowered, stepping over systems designed to keep things in check.

This is then made worse by the accompanying glitch, where those constantly top-notch weapons also need never run out of bullets to fire. Again, the top-tier arms have very scarce, expensive ammo, designed to restrict use and prevent domination. But by swapping weapons over, not only do they get repaired, but they‚Äôll also fill an ammo slot. Do this, drop the weapon, pick it up, unload it, drop the ammo and pick that up again, and it‚Äôs yours to keep. And yes, this is much more cumbersome, and hardly useful for a rapid-fire automatic weapon, but when it comes to something like a Hullcracker with its super-rare explosive projectiles, it‚Äôs a huge issue. And it gets far worse.

JUST FOUND NEW MONEY GLITCH FOR AMMO LOL #ArcRaiders pic.twitter.com/r4t5oYin41

‚Äî perc (@genos) February 11, 2026

It turns out if you use the swapping trick on guns like the Anvil and the Venator, you end up with 102 bullets loaded in guns that are supposed to only hold six and 22 bullets respectively. You can also get the 35-bullet rapid-firing Bobcat to load itself with 102 rounds, which is wildly OP. In a shoot-out, this is obviously a massive advantage, and unlike the ammo-duping glitch above, it‚Äôs trivially easy to do. Given that, who wouldn‚Äôt load up with 102 bullets, even if they‚Äôre just trying to take on the machines?

NAH THIS INFINITE AMMO GLITCH IS FUCKING BROKEN @EmbarkStudios @ArcRaiderAlerts @THump pic.twitter.com/IGgreMZXWE

‚Äî perc (@genos) February 11, 2026

It‚Äôs worth noting that Arc Raiders doesn‚Äôt have anything like betwixt-player trading markets, so no one‚Äôs getting taken advantage of by these schemes, and as such there‚Äôs no internal economy that‚Äôs broken by such exploits. (There is unofficial trading in-game, where you can swap out items with people you encounter, and this can be exploited for ill gains, but it‚Äôs not going to cause major harm.) The issue is far more about an individual player‚Äôs progress being artificially boosted, with them able to sell ammo to in-game traders for extra cash, and especially for PVP players getting far better equipped when battling other people.

I imagine we‚Äôll see an emergency hotfix rolled out pretty sharpish, but in the meantime, perhaps focus on the freshly released Shared Watch event where players are encouraged to work together to fight the machines. And remember, the game‚Äôs matchmaking deliberately assigns you to games with players of a similar temperament, so if you‚Äôre PVP-averse, you‚Äôre far more likely to be put into lobbies with raiders of a similar nature.

item.title: Pok√©mon Pokopia Features ‚ÄòMore Things to Experience‚Äô After End Credits
item.content:encoded:
The director of Pok√©mon Pokopia has revealed how many hours players would spend in the game and that experiences await after the end credits.

Pok√©mon Pokopia was announced for the Switch 2 during the Pok√©mon Presents showcase last year. Since then, we have received the March 4 release date for the title and a new trailer featuring Pikachu and Snorlax variants. Also, a leak has confirmed the theory about Pok√©mon Pokopia taking place in a post-apocalyptic world.Now, the developers have finally revealed some new information about the upcoming title.

Pok√©mon Pokopia Will be About 20-40 Hours Long

item.title: Reanimal wants to devour you
item.content:encoded:
The woods in Reanimal are full of surprises. You will encounter human cadavers that slither like snakes, gigantic talking pigs, and, at one point, a forlorn, supersized whale who seems resigned to an agonizingly slow death. These variously monstrous beings inhabit a realm that, though it looks like our own, seems to defy spatial logic: the forest leads to an oceanic expanse, which segues into a decrepit, towering city. It‚Äôs like Aesop‚Äôs Fables meets the nightmare visions of both Lars von Trier and J.G. Ballard.

Playing as a boy and girl (either solo or via local / online co-op), Reanimal evolves the premise Tarsier Studios explored with its first two Little Nightmares games: the timeless terror of children being pursued by larger, looming monsters. But the camera in this action-platformer is more fluid and dynamic. It feels less like you are peering inside a doll‚Äôs house and more like you are seamlessly directing these characters through a miniature film set. Another notable departure: For all its unsettling darkness, Little Nightmares always carried a little storybook charm. That quality is largely absent here. Reanimal is darker, nastier ‚Äî and stronger for it.

The game begins on water, with you following dimly lit buoys; you reach a beach and open washed-up suitcases to find a key. From there, you venture into what seems like a hydroelectric facility. Inside, there are light puzzles to solve as you move forward, though nothing so taxing as to impede your progress for very long. The pair you‚Äôre controlling (referred to simply as ‚ÄúBoy‚Äù and ‚ÄúGirl‚Äù) can jump and grab objects; later, they wield a crowbar, useful for prying open doors or whacking smaller enemies. If you have played either a Little Nightmares game or a title by Playdead (the Danish studio‚Äôs landmark first game Limbo or 2016 classic Inside), then the action will feel instantly familiar.

The revelatory moments arrive via finely crafted details: These child protagonists carefully and reassuringly usher one another into each newly discovered room. I love how upon each restart after dying (perhaps in the jaws of a monstrous foe or by tumbling down a sheer drop), the duo are shown hugging one another ‚Äî the only comfort they have in this terrible world.

Yet these children are made of steely stuff. For every panicked sequence fleeing a gigantic sheep down a blood-red corridor, there is a moment when it is these youngsters who are doing the chasing. Reanimal, like forebears dating all the way back to 1991‚Äôs Another World, delights in showing you enemy figures loping ominously off-screen through some crack or hole in the wall. You must follow, plucking up the courage to trail these beasts into inky shadows.

Reanimal takes some time revealing where its strikingly macabre, exquisitely haunted images are leading. The key moment occurs with the arrival of a soldier wearing a Brodie helmet popular in World War I; a few scenes later, you discover coastal artillery. Tarsier toyed with wartime motifs in its Little Nightmares games, notably the pile of shoes that recalled the heaps of belongings found by Allied soldiers at Nazi extermination camps in West Germany. Reanimal‚Äôs allegory is more explicit: At one particularly gruesome moment, you must evade the shots of a sniper stationed high in a building. Fail to find cover quickly enough and the young boy or girl‚Äôs body is ripped apart by a speeding bullet.

Tarsier‚Äôs latest operates in a different tonal zone to the jingoistic, popcorn warfare of the Call of Duty series and the amped-up-to-11 absurdity of Battlefield. Its solemnity evokes the trench sequences from the first Death Stranding game and finely calibrated dread of 2024‚Äôs underrated survival-horror title Conscript and action-adventure Hell Is Us.

That said, for all Reanimal‚Äôs achievements, it falls just a little short of greatness. The game doesn‚Äôt possess the same crystalline, airtight polish of Playdead‚Äôs work. Some transitions between scenes are a little abrupt, and on a few occasions, I had to reload because of a glitching character. Such is the literal darkness of the game, coupled with the choices of perspective, that distinguishing between the fore and background is a struggle; cue the odd accidental fall.

None of this greatly impacts what is a frequently bold and brilliant game. Since 2017, Tarsier has made children‚Äôs nightmares for grown-ups; despite its young protagonists, Reanimal is a nightmare wholly born from the anxieties of adults. It seems to speak to both the horrors of the 20th century and our barbarous present in which large-scale on-the-ground conflicts between sovereign nations have regretfully reemerged.

I‚Äôm still running the story‚Äôs deeper meaning through my head. But regardless of the conclusions I eventually draw, there is no denying the sheer verve and power of the images that Tarsier summons on screen. Bodies ‚Äî human or otherwise ‚Äî disappear into bodies; children are doomed to wield the weapons of grown-ups (if they are not torn asunder by them first). The game also harbors a fascination with the spectacle of popular entertainment, delivering showstopping moments in both a cinema and theater.

Reanimal does not flinch; this action-platformer delivers a parade of atrocities you cannot take your eyes off of.

Reanimal launches February 13th on the PS5, Xbox, PC, and Nintendo Switch 2.

item.title: Zero Parades and Disco Elysium Developer ZA/UM on AI: ‚ÄòWe Don‚Äôt Use It‚Äô
item.content:encoded:
‚ÄúI want a really human experience, right? I don't want a computer-driven creation.‚Äù

It‚Äôs pretty safe to say that generative artificial intelligence has become a divisive issue within the games industry and wider player community. As the technology becomes more prevalent, companies and studios are being pushed to offer clarity on their use of it. Within the past few months alone, Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 developer Larian has faced significant backlash against its use of generative AI, and RuneScape studio Jagex has promised no AI will be used for any assets a player can ‚Äútouch, hear or feel.‚Äù

ZA/UM, the developer behind Disco Elysium and the upcoming Zero Parades: For Dead Spies, has offered its view on the issue, and it‚Äôs a pretty simple one: ‚ÄúNo AI.‚Äù

Talking to IGN, ZA/UM‚Äôs head of studio, Allen Murray, offered his perspective on the situation: ‚ÄúI think about the world right now, where everybody's dealing with AI in a creative space, and what I see is there'll be a hunger for this singer-songwriter in a cafe. I want a really human experience, right? I don't want a computer-driven creation.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think we'll see more of that,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúThere's always this desire for storytelling and something created by humans that has meaning, that you can relate to. And so I think there'll be a resurgence in that.‚Äù

When pushed to clarify the studio‚Äôs stance on the technology, Murray gave a simple statement. ‚ÄúNo AI,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAs a stance, we don't use it.‚Äù

Jim Ashilevi, writer and VO director at ZA/UM, added, ‚ÄúIt's all just us being messy and human all the way through. And if it's embarrassing, and if it's not as polished as it would be if you went and used AI or whatever, that's fine. Because all we really care about is just being ourselves, basically.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can feel it when you play our games,‚Äù continued Ashilevi. ‚ÄúYou can see and feel the fingerprints of real human beings when you exist in those worlds and when you read the stories that we like to tell. I think there's a certain rugged and kind of unpolished quality to the kinds of stories and worlds we like to create.‚Äù

Artificial intelligence and large language models (LLMs) were not particularly prevalent during the development of Disco Elysium, but during the creation of Zero Parades they have risen to become a major force in the world of tech. Google‚Äôs new ‚ÄúProject Genie‚Äù AI tech has demonstrated a (very limited) ability to create playable worlds based on simple prompts, while Sony has patented AI systems that create podcasts hosted by PlayStation characters and an assist function that can help players overcome challenges in video games. Not every creative is convinced though, with Rockstar‚Äôs co-founder Dan Houser suggesting that AI is akin to ‚Äúwhen we fed cows with cows and got mad cow disease.‚Äù

ZA/UM‚Äôs vision for its new RPG is rooted in traditional development processes, through which it hopes to create a story about ‚Äúwhat it means to lose everything and then keep going regardless.‚Äù

Matt Purslow is IGN's Executive Editor of Features.

item.title: Pok√©mon Pokopia - The Final Preview
item.content:encoded:
To me, and I‚Äôm sure many others, the Pok√©mon franchise as a whole has always been ‚Äúcozy.‚Äù Set in a (mostly) idyllic world with cute best friends who are always by your side, how could it not give you warm fuzzy feelings at least occasionally? We‚Äôve had some relaxing Pok√©mon games over the years, but we‚Äôve never quite had a game that embraced this secondary cozy aesthetic fully into its gameplay‚Äìuntil now, with Pok√©mon Pokopia. I played the first hour of Pok√©mon‚Äôs first life-sim, and the sheer amount of discovery to be made hooked me. I also played Pok√©mon Pokopia in multiplayer mode in a more developed world, plus, I learned more straight from the developers.

Pok√©mon Pokopia begins with a Ditto waking up after a long, undefined slumber. It remembers its trainer in its hometown, with the nameless narrator commenting, ‚ÄúYou look so happy with your trainer petting you!‚Äù

Aw, that is so sweet, and so sad‚ÄìDitto‚Äôs trainer is nowhere to be found, and that‚Äôs Ditto‚Äôs‚Äì(you, the protagonist‚Äôs)‚Äìmotivator. In a bid to try to find its trainer, Ditto transforms into a human that looks like its trainer the best they can. Enter the character creator, in which you get to choose between seven hairstyles, 28 haircolors, hats, clothes, and bags. No, you can‚Äôt just be purple, that wouldn‚Äôt be very human-like!

‚ÄúI wanted to create something where you can directly communicate with Pok√©mon,‚Äù Ohmori said.‚Äú

Shigeru Ohmori, the primary director of Pok√©mon games since 2014 and Pok√©mon Pokopia‚Äôs Concept and Senior Director, explained the thought behind making a Pok√©mon the main character and why it transforms into a human. ‚ÄúI wanted to create something where you can directly communicate with Pok√©mon,‚Äù Ohmori said.

Ohmori worried if they had a trainer as the playable character, as in the other mainline titles, it becomes the trainer giving orders to Pok√©mon, which they wanted to avoid. By keeping it all Pok√©mon, an atmosphere of friendship and teamwork is created.

There are two reasons Ohmori decided to make specifically Ditto the main character, too: one to benefit the gameplay, and another to benefit the story. Because Ditto can transform into other Pok√©mon and use their moves, it was the best option (I argue Mew could fit that bill too, but of course Mew wouldn‚Äôt have those adorable ‚Äúsimple eyes and slack mouth,‚Äù as Professor Tangrowth puts it.)

Pok√©mon Pokopia Screenshots

The other reason feeds the narrative motivations of Pok√©mon Pokopia. No one else knows what Ditto‚Äôs trainer looks like, so Ditto transforming into the trainer it misses is essentially asking the other Pok√©mon, ‚ÄúDo you know this human being?‚Äù Again, so cute, so melancholic, and I love it.

An Unobtrusive Tutorial

The tutorial, fortunately, is nicely integrated into what would be the regular flow of gameplay, and lets you start doing stuff outside its confines very quickly.

After meeting Professor Tangrowth, I found the Pokedex, and then found my first‚Äìthen second‚Äìthen third‚ÄìPok√©mon friend, expanding my abilities and how I could affect the world with each one, further enhancing my ability to create a wider variety of habitats to attract a wider variety of Pok√©mon.

Pok√©mon Pokopia Concept Art

Bulbasaur taught me the move Leafage, allowing me to create tall grass at will. Squirtle taught me the move Water Gun, so I could revitalize the dry ground and grass in the aptly named Withered Wasteland, the environment you start in. Charmander didn‚Äôt teach me a move, but instead taught me that you can ask Pok√©mon to follow you somewhere so they can perform an action based on their Specialty. In Charmander‚Äôs case, they lit a fire for me. As for other Specialty examples, Tiburr‚Äôs Build helps you build structures, and Bulbasaur‚Äôs Grow, makes plants grow faster.

Of course, to find more Pok√©mon, you need to make a variety of Habitats. The most basic habitat is four squares of tall grass, easily made by Leafage. You can also move objects around with Ditto‚Äôs ability to store and then spit-up materials, like, a Punching Bag. This is, canonically, the move Stockpile. Holding the collect button down actually makes Ditto continuously suck up anything around it, causing its face to hilariously and disturbingly resemble The Scream painting.

Other habitats include ones like the self-described ‚ÄúBoulder-shaded tall grass,‚Äù which attracts Fighting-type Pok√©mon like Timburr and Machop, and ‚ÄúHydrated flower bed,‚Äù made of four flower beds placed beside‚Äìyou guessed it‚Äìwater. After a bit of time passes, a square in your new habitat may shake, indicating there‚Äôs a Pok√©mon there to meet.

Like the Pokedex for tracking Pok√©mon, there‚Äôs a Habitat dex for tracking habitats, and there are quite a number to discover!

Though I loved just experimenting, it isn‚Äôt all completely guess work. Occasionally, you‚Äôll find a sparkle on the ground that‚Äôs a ‚Äútrace of Pok√©mon‚Äù which gives you a hint about a yet-to-be-found Pok√©mon‚Äôs preferred habitat you haven‚Äôt discovered yet.

The Core Loop - All Pokemon All the Time

This cycle of attracting new Pok√©mon, learning new skills oivr discovering new specialties from them, then making more new habitats to attract even more new Pok√©mon, is the corest-of-core loops in Pok√©mon Pokopia, and is already incredibly engaging and fun without even considering the crafting and world customization you can do. This isn‚Äôt an accident.

‚ÄúWhen thinking about development of the game, [the team] started thinking about the cycles of the user's motivation,‚Äù said Takuto Edagawa of KOEITECMO GAMES, Pok√©mon Pokopia Chief Director. ‚ÄúWhat the user wants to do, what they would want to start to do within the cycle. So, for example, filling up the Pokedex or creating more habitats, then that would create meeting more Pok√©mon.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvery single step in the game,‚Äù Edagawa continued, ‚ÄúThe core of it is to be with the Pok√©mon, communicating with Pok√©mon. So wherever you go, there is always Pok√©mon‚Ä¶ that is the largest difference compared to other [life sim] games.‚Äù

This core cycle that focuses on the Pok√©mon first and foremost is ingrained into the ‚Äúmain objectives‚Äù that propel the story as well. Just after meeting the Kanto Starters, you discover a decrepit Pok√©mon Center nearby. The PC there automatically launches the Poke Life Environment Improvement App, which dishes out both important tasks tied to progression, like increasing an area‚Äôs Environment Level or rebuilding the Pokemon Center; and smaller daily objectives, like collecting a certain number of sturdy sticks.

Bulbasaur specifically asked for a bed, so I crafted a Straw Bed from leaves for them. ‚Äú

The stick collecting is self-explanatory, but to increase the Environment Level of the area, you must attract more Pok√©mon and improve their Comfort Levels. Again, another touch point with Pok√©mon.

Placing furniture a Pok√©mon wants within the bounds of its habitat‚Äìwhich you can see by pressing in on the R-stick‚Äìwill increase its Comfort Level. Bulbasaur, for example, specifically asked for a bed, so I crafted a Straw Bed from leaves for them.

The Poke Life app rewarded me for my efforts with new unlocks and Life Coins. These can be used to buy a variety of things at the PC, like furniture, seeds, Pok√©mon hints, building recipes, and more. After increasing the Environment Level, Professor Tangrowth had more for me, too.

Multiplayer and More

There seems to be a lot more to Pokopia than everything I already talked about. I haven‚Äôt even touched on building buildings or what looks to be a huge number of collectibles‚Äìlike Human Records, which included things like a diary that gave a glimpse of what Professor Tangrowth‚Äôs life was like with their human, and a document on Pok√©mon Greetings that taught me an emote!

The four-player multiplayer session gave me a look at a developed world, where Pok√©mon‚Äôs Habitat‚Äôs were developed so thoroughly they lived inside houses! The inside of the houses had furniture and decorations, like plushies, and the little town was manicured with sidewalks, fences, lamp posts, and even a stage.

My time with multiplayer was short, and I‚Äôm restricted from what exactly I can reveal, so I can‚Äôt say much more about it besides that it was fun. I can see friends ushering each other to stay on task, because it is just so easy to get distracted in Pok√©mon Pokopia, and that sounds like the best kind of hectic. (I was that friend in my group. I‚Äôm sorry!)

Edagawa said that, on average, depending on how you play Pok√©mon Pokopia, it will take between 20 and 40 hours to reach the ‚Äúend‚Äù credits. But, that‚Äôs not really the main motivation to play Pok√©mon Pokopia‚Äìit‚Äôs to make a world to live with Pok√©mon. As for the post game, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more things to experience after the end credits‚Ä¶ I believe that players are encouraged to and will be motivated to continue to play the game,‚Äù Edagawa said.

There will also be motivation for players to log in intermittently. Pok√©mon Pokopia Producer Kanako Murata of The Pokemon Company said ‚ÄúWhen you play day-by-day, there may be something that, on a specific day, something special that might happen in the game.‚Äù

Considering how many hours some friends of mine have put into Animal Crossing: New Horizons, I think they‚Äôre right, especially for those whose motivations are to create a unique place to live with Pok√©mon. For me, I hope Ditto and the crew learn what happened to create this apocalyptic, empty world, but regardless, I‚Äôm excited to restore it with my best Pok√©mon friends.

item.title: Pok√©mon Pokopia Will Take 20-40 Hours to Beat on Average, and There's More After the Credits, Says Director
item.content:encoded:
Pok√©mon's upcoming Dragon Quest Builders-like sandbox, Pokopia, isn't just a Pok√©mon-themed block-building playground. It has a main story that some are suggesting has some post-apocalyptic vibes to it, and according to the game's director, it can take anywhere from 20 to 40 hours to finish... with more to do after the credits.

This comes from our own interview with Takuto Edagawa, the chief director of Pok√©mon Pokopia. We asked about the approximate length of the game, and this was the response:

So for this game, the main motivation for this game is typically not to go to the end roll [credits]. The whole concept is to create the world with Pokemon and live with the Pokemon. However, as an average, it'll be about 20 to 40 hours, but it would really depend on how the players play the game.
There's more things to experience after the end roll [credits]. So it depends on what you mean by contents, but I believe that players are encouraged to and will be motivated to continue to play the game.

This fairly open-ended response isn't a surprise given what we know of Pokopia. It's a sandboxy sim where you, a Ditto transformed into a human shape, hang out on an initially deserted island and get to work building habitats to convince more Pokemon friends to come live with you. It's very similar to Dragon Quest Builders, which makes sense as the developer, Omega Force, also helped out on Dragon Quest Builders 2. In addition to the story component, we can imagine this will have some fairly open-ended gameplay as to what you build, where, and how, and its multiplayer components will likely give the game some longevity too. As a result, it makes sense that players would have a wide range of completion times based on how much they dig into the building mechanics both during and after the campaign.

We also got a chance to go hands-on with Pokopia, including its four-player multiplayer offering, and experience its cozy, mysterious world for ourselves. The game is planned for release on Nintendo Switch 2 on March 5, 2026.

Bernard Kim, former president of publishing at mobile developer Zynga and member of the board of directors at Five Below, has been appointed to Unity's own board of directors.

Kim, who spent close to a decade at EA earlier in his career, will join the board as an independent director on May 1, 2026. He said he intends help the engine maker accelerate its mission to "democratize game development."

In a note to investors, board chairman Jim Whitehurst praised the appointment.

"Bernard brings deep experience building and scaling global, public companies at the intersection of games and technology," said Whitehurst. "His leadership across mobile gaming, advertising technology, and consumer platforms will be a valuable addition to the Unity Board."

Unity also confirmed that company co-founder David Helgason and ironSource co-founder Tomer Bar-Zeev stepped down from the board on February 5.

"David and Tomer have been vital partners as we've grown and transformed Unity," said Matt Bromberg, president and CEO of Unity. "They welcomed me into the company, shared their unique vision as founders, and have provided unfailing support. I‚Äôm looking forward to many more years of conversation with both of them."

Unity had an eventful 2025. In late February, the company cut ties with over 1,700 workers and confirmed it had shut down 23 offices in 2024. In March, after the runtime fee debacle, Unity's CEO and CTO promised "stability."

In July, former Unity senior client partner Rod Stafford was jailed for 22 years over sexual offenses. That same month, the company promised strong AI copyright "guardrails" after an employee conjured Mickey Mouse on stream.

Still, Unity lauded its AI-powered ad platform in August after Q2 results exceeded expectations, and proceeded to form an AI council to "accelerate AI product innovation." 

According to the 2026 State of the Game Industry report, 36 percent of game industry professionals are using generative AI tools as part of their job. Half of them, however, think the technology has a negative impact on the industry, echoing concerns and skepticism throughout last year.

item.title: No one read too much into these new Star Craft action figures, OK
item.content:encoded:
Nothing to see here folks, save for the figurine lovers I'm sure.

Joy Toy, a popular figurine production company, has announced a line of small-scale Starcraft models as part of a collaboration with Activision Blizzard.

In a blog post to the official Joy Toy website, the company announced it'll be making models for the Zerg, Protos, and Terran. Exactly what those models are remains a mystery for now, as they're silhouetted in the announcement post. Details on product information and pre-order schedules are set to come in the future via Joy Toy channels.

These figurines will be a compact size of roughly 10cm, with seemingly five available split across the three playable StarCraft factions.

While it is worth noting that this post explicitly states these models are "based on the characters from the classic game, StarCraft," the announcement does come at an interesting time for Blizzard and the StarCraft IP.

Not only is 2026 a milestone year for Blizzard, with multiple big announcements teased for Blizzcon later this year, but rumours are circulating around a new StarCraft game in-development at Arc Raiders publisher Nexon. If these reports are accurate, this game's development would coincide with big shifts at Hearthstone (though not Hearthstone 2) and a massive Overwatch resurgence.

It is, of course, also possible that these figurines are just a nice nostalgic way to show your love for the original StarCraft, and that nothing is going on with StarCraft as the IP remains dormant. It's totally possible. Place your bets, folks!

item.title: Review: Reanimal (Switch 2) - Little Nightmares Team Delivers Its Darkest, Boldest Vision Yet
item.content:encoded:
If you‚Äôre a horror fan and you own a Switch 2, you should play Reanimal. From the moment it pulls you into its bleak, nightmarish world, it‚Äôs clear that developer Tarsier Studios is building on everything it learned from the Little Nightmares series while pushing its signature horror sensibilities to unnerving new heights.

This is an ambitious evolution of the cinematic horror puzzle-platformer formula the studio helped define with Little Nightmares, one that plays out less linearly in larger 3D spaces, with more varied combat and traversal mechanics and bombastic set pieces. It does so with impeccable sound design, gorgeous lighting, and pitch-perfect atmosphere.

Reanimal marks a shift from the Tim Burton-esque macabre of the studio‚Äôs earlier titles towards what, by the end, feels closer to the shell-shocked horror of Elem Klimov‚Äôs war film Come and See, infused with the profane supernatural. Its moments of pulse-pounding escalation overwhelm the senses, while quieter stretches seethe with tension and fear of the unknown.

There are small points of friction along the way, whether in busier encounters that can briefly disorient or in lengthy load times that occasionally interrupt the otherwise seamless flow. Even so, these are minor frustrations in a game that so consistently delivers on its vision, and they do little to dull the impact of its world, atmosphere, or stellar set-piece design.

Narratively, you play as a brother and sister venturing through a hellish world in an effort to rescue their missing friends, a simple setup that effectively supports the game‚Äôs focus on co-operative survival. There is well-executed voice acting that elevates certain moments and sheds light on the predicament facing the characters, though instances of it are sparse.

Reanimal is fully playable in single-player, which pairs you with an AI companion, but it supports local and online co-op with GameShare, too. The game frequently requires its protagonists to act in tandem ‚Äì flipping switches simultaneously or coordinating actions to progress ‚Äì and both playable characters function identically, with no mechanical advantage given to either.

My review is primarily based on my time playing solo, and the companion AI generally keeps pace, responds reliably to prompts, and does a solid job supporting the game‚Äôs more demanding sequences, particularly during chases and combat. Rare moments of awkward AI behaviour self-resolved and were typically tied to puzzle conditions not yet being met.

Compared to the playable protagonists of Little Nightmares, who often feel almost doll-like ‚Äì underpowered, limited in their movement, and unable to reach the height of door knobs ‚Äì the characters in Reanimal are larger and more mechanically capable, while the core loop of escaping a hostile space by cleverly eluding and besting an area‚Äôs apex threat remains intact.

While Little Nightmares is built around a side-scrolling progression, Reanimal‚Äôs environments are far more intricate and non-linear, requiring exploration and backtracking to find the tools needed to overcome obstacles. There are traversal mechanics through the use of a boat and other vehicles, though it‚Äôs best to avoid detailing them here to prevent spoilers.

The game also includes light melee combat, primarily against enemies of your own size, with the companion AI mirroring the player‚Äôs actions, attacking in tandem or raising a light source to illuminate the surrounding darkness. The game‚Äôs lighting and colour palette is genuinely gorgeous, yet it‚Äôs frequently unafraid to plunge you into pitch-black darkness.

Given just how dark the lighting can be at times, it‚Äôs worth noting that a small white indicator appears when you get close to objects like hatches and levers that can be interacted with, as well as cracks in walls you can squeeze through, which feels like thoughtful environmental design that guides the player without being intrusive or breaking immersion.

That said, it‚Äôs still possible to overlook smaller items, such as a key on the floor or a tool required for a puzzle amidst a cluttered space, which can briefly stall progression until they‚Äôre discovered. These objects are marked by a subtle white outline when approached, but spotting them can occasionally require visual skimming of the environment.

There are a variety of well-hidden collectables scattered throughout, including masks that your characters can wear, which are typically tucked away behind easy-to-miss hidden rooms. Reanimal‚Äôs relentlessly grim world is also dotted with flyers pinned to walls, which unlock concept art and offer an additional incentive to explore off the beaten path.

The game‚Äôs audio design also stands out, especially when played with headphones. Ominous bellows, grinding factory machinery, creaky floorboards, howling wind through open spaces, blaring car alarms, and a barrage of abrasive noises sharply heighten the stress and tension, especially as you‚Äôre tailed by no shortage of horrid things during chase sequences.

A recurring frustration I had with Tarsier‚Äôs previous game, Little Nightmares II, was the use of encounters that leaned too heavily into trial and error and instant deaths, often requiring repeated attempts to progress. Attempting a section over and over broke my immersion and diminished the scare factor. Reanimal does a better job of minimising such friction.

There are a few moments where repetition is difficult to avoid simply because it‚Äôs easy to misunderstand what the game is asking of you, such as when player characters are forced to traverse a crumbling multi-forked path while tied together. But arguably the game‚Äôs biggest fault is that it can sometimes take more than 15 seconds to reload after you die.

You can complete Reanimal within four to five hours, but there‚Äôs no padding. While the first act perhaps too closely resembles Little Nightmares, from the design of its antagonist to the rhythm of its environmental puzzling, Reanimal steadily sets itself apart visually and narratively as it progresses, while gameplay becomes far more varied and ambitious.

The game‚Äôs final act culminates in a genuinely thrilling spectacle that leaves behind layers of lore for diehard players to unpack. By the time the credits roll, everything the game has been building towards comes together in a way that feels greater than the sum of its parts. It marks Tarsier Studios‚Äô best work to date and a confident evolution of their creative vision.

Conclusion

With Reanimal, Tarsier Studios delivers its darkest, boldest work yet. Expanding on the Little Nightmares formula with non-linear exploration, striking audiovisual design, and bombastic set pieces, this is an imaginative horror experience that confidently delivers its vision while offering accessible co-op play that fans of the developer have long clamoured for.

item.title: MercurySteam‚Äôs Blades of Fire Arrives on Steam This May With ‚ÄúVersion 2.0,‚Äù Adds NG+, NVIDIA DLSS 4 Support, and More
item.content:encoded:
MercurySteam, the developer behind the critically acclaimed 2D action game, Metroid Dread, followed up its beloved Nintendo-exclusive outing with something completely different last year. Blades of Fire was a new 3D action-adventure game that saw you take the role of Aran de Lira, the last blacksmith capable of wielding and forging true steel, who is tasked with killing the Queen to save humanity.

When it launched in May 2025, Wccftech's Francesco De Meo reviewed it, and despite it lacking in originality with its fantasy setting and narrative, he praised the weapon variety and forging mechanics, giving it an 8.5/10. A crucial point on its launch, however, was that it was only available on PC as an Epic Game Store exclusive. Now, developer MercurySteam has announced that it is finally making its arrival on Steam, and it'll do so with a new and improved "Version 2.0."

It'll arrive on Steam on May 14, 2026, and if you're keen to get your hands on it before then, you'll be to play a demo that's live right now to help celebrate its Steam release and to participate in Steam Next Fest, which is due to officially start in two weeks at the time of this writing.

As for what's new in Version 2.0, players will be able to dig into a new difficulty level called "Titanium" to really test their forging and fighting skills. Element transmutation has been added to allow players to change material types. There's a new photo mode, new game plus (which also includes new weapon parts and skins only available in NG+), and a new boss revival mode that lets you replay boss fights. Crucially, you can also now pet the Ox.

Outside of new gameplay additions, Version 2.0 also includes several technical updates and improvements, including adding support for NVIDIA DLSS 4, support for Steam Deck, new achievements and full key remapping for keyboard and mouse controls. The Steam version will also come with the game's original soundtrack and an artbook as part of the Adventure Pack, though anyone who owns the game on the Epic Games Store or consoles will have to grab the Adventure Pack separately.
